Sorry that I can't provide any productive convo, but I must say that every Russian movie I've ever seen sucks borscht.

 No, no favourites my knowledge of Russian/Soviet cinema is not as extensive as yours. I would not say I am a 'fan' either of a particular national cinema, just that I've seen a number of films that I like :)
 As for genre, I'm more a sci-fi/horror fan, and will look at these no matter where in the world they're from - as long as they're good... thus I am aware of some Russian/Soviet films such as "Amphibian Man" et al.
 I won't receive my copy of "Night Watch" for about two weeks - owing to the distance it has to travel... so don't give away the plot... just let me know if you liked it.

Ok. For a Sci-Fi fan, the following, that I already mentioned, are a must:
 Solaris, Stalker, Kin-Dza-Dza
 Also animated feature "The Secret of the Third Planet" is really good.

I've recently made a page that lists English language movies that are based on Russian books. So far I have 26 titles listed. And I'm trying to find more. The ones I really liked are: Lolita, Onegin & Doctor Zhivago. Would appreciate any help with the ones I've missed.
 
 PS: Montalban, your commie comment (joke ?) was way too Cold War for me.

"Night watch" is in American theaters now ("Lord of the Rings" meets "Prophecy"). It's been out on DVD for some time, but since Fox bought all American distribution rights, they have mandated to stop making NTSC formatted dvds of it. The disk has been slowly disappearing from even Russian stores in America. And Fox kept postponing the release until limited release on friday, while sequel "Day Watch" is already out in Russia on pal dvd (without subs only). Both installments beat American movies in Russia on dvd pal. And the studio is insisting on filming the 3rd part in English. Ain't US movie studios wonderful emoticon_rolleyes

Night watch does have some parts in english (or at least in the version I saw in the cinema) where they tell you the backstory. Its also clearly marketed at the internation market as they do cool things with the subtitles as well.
 
 As for the plot - various mythical creatures (including wizards and psychics) exist in two factions, good and evil (though its not quite that clean cut), these factions almost anhillated each other in a war centuries past and have come to a truce. A human is used as bait in a stong operation by the Night watch (who make sure the Evil Others don't break the truce) when he goes to a 'witch' to get revenge on his girlfriend who has left him after becoming pregnant with someone else's child.
 
 Craziness ensues as various were creatures burst in before the ritual completes and he tries to hide, ending up in a parallel realm known as the Dark. Whilst in the Dark, Others are invisiable to humans though they can't stay there long without their live forces being consumed. Just in time he returns to the reworld and is picked up by the Night Watch and trained as one of them.
 
 Cut to several years later when as a Seer, he is posing as a vampire to track down some strange goings on amongst the Dark Others. Over the course of the investigation he gets in trouble with the Day Watch (who make sure the Good Others don't try to break the truce) only to eventually find out that someone he randomly bumped into on the course of the investigation is more important than he first thought.
 
 Only critism is that the two main female characters (the human ones, rather than the Others) look too much alike and without hearing their voices are easily confused. Its a lot better if you remember that they are different.
 
 Sequal is Day Watch (which is obvious when you've watched it) and is followed by Dawn Watch (which I have no idea about). From what I heard the intention was always to get these on the international market, its not some oppertune approach by hollywood but the Russian producers realising that english speaking countries are a huge market and a nessesary step for international recognition. Who really cares which films win best in a foriegn language, its generally in the wrong language for 90% of the world to understand, they do recognise mass market hollywood starts though.
